attributes.title: Search and Raw Search Result Citation Files
attributes.description: This dataset is part of a study that used scoping review methodology to collect and verify the applicability of the phrase "Food Studies" in bibliographic records across five databases. Five large bibliographic databases were identified for size, relevance to food studies, and subject metadata standards. These were ProQuest Central (PQC), EBSCO Discovery Service (EDS), Web Of Science (WOS), PubMed (PM), and PubAg. The phrase “food studies” was then searched within each database, using a scholarly or peer-reviewed filter. The date range for the articles was all-time, through the date of the final search (December 3, 2019.)

attributes.title: The "Food Studies" Corpus
attributes.description:
This dataset is part of a study that used scoping review methodology to collect and verify the applicability of the phrase "Food Studies" in bibliographic records across five databases. Five large bibliographic databases were identified for size, relevance to food studies, and subject metadata standards. These were ProQuest Central (PQC), EBSCO Discovery Service (EDS), Web Of Science (WOS), PubMed (PM), and PubAg. The phrase “food studies” was then searched within each database, using a scholarly or peer-reviewed filter. The date range for the articles was all-time, through the date of the final search (December 3, 2019.) 

Each database’s search results were exported, transferred, and pooled into bibliographic management software (EndNote). Using endnote, the author verified “food studies” in the metadata, and prepared the metadata for screening. (No deduplication methods were used in this or the next phase because metadata can differ between duplicates.) Eligibility criteria for results were determined to be any peer-reviewed article’s record that contained data in its keyword, index term, subject, or heading fields, and had the phrase “food studies” anywhere in its metadata. 

The results were then imported into ES management software (Covidence), where all records were screened for relevance or irrelevance. Two major exclusion parameters were used in this phase. The first was whether the phrase “food studies” was lexically written as a plural or uncountable noun. Secondarily, I conducted background research for unfamiliar uses of “food studies” as a concept.

Once completed, this set of citations constituted The “Food Studies” Corpus. Because keyword frequency results rely on counting exact textual strings from five different database sources, the keywords needed to be crosswalked, or clustered and merged. Textual differences were cleaned through algorithmic clustering.The corpus was prepared and exported into a tabular document. This tabbed-corpus was then imported into data cleaning software (OpenRefine). OpenRefine contains several clustering methods. The number of keywords and clusters for each method, used in succession, can be found in "Keyword Clustering" spreadsheet. (Note that each text cluster was manually evaluated before merging—no merge was automatic.)

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

registration_responses.datacompletion: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

attributes.title: Self-Compassion and Prejudice
attributes.description:
The overall purpose of the study is to investigate the relation between self-compassion and
negative attitudes toward outgroups.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit up to 187 students from Rutgers University, Newark. The sample size was calculated using G*Power software (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner & Lang, 2009) to detect a correlation between self-compassion and negative attitudes toward an outgroup with a small effect size r = .25, α = .05, 1 – β = 95%, with an estimated participant dropout rate of 10%.

analyses.value:
Hypothesis 1: Zero-order correlations will be conducted to examine the correlations between all the measured variables, including self-compassion, compassion for others, self-esteem, social dominance orientation, and attitudes toward outgroups including homeless and Asian people, senior citizens, and Christians. 
Hypothesis 2: Mediation analysis will be used to investigate if compassion for others will mediate the relationship between self-compassion and attitudes toward:
o	Hypothesis 2a. homeless people. 
o	Hypothesis 2b. Asian people.
o	Hypothesis 2c. senior citizens.
o	Hypothesis 2d. Christians.

dependent.value:
Self-Compassion: Neff’s Self-Compassion Scale (2003)
Prejudiced Attitudes Against an Outgroup: (1) feeling thermometers, (2) competency ratings, (3) semantic differentials, and (4) affective attitudes scale (Cuddy, Fiske, & Glick, 2007)
Social Dominance Orientation: Social Dominance Orientation Scale (Ho et al., 2015)
Self-Esteem: Rosenberg’s Self-Esteem Scale (1989)
Compassion for Others: Compassion Scale (Pommier, Neff, & Tóth-Király, 2019)

hypothesis.value:
Hypothesis 1. Self-compassion will be negatively correlated with negative attitudes toward outgroups and social dominance orientation.
Hypothesis 2: Compassion for others will mediate the relationship between self-compassion and attitudes toward outgroups. Higher levels of self-compassion will lead to higher levels of compassion for others and, thus, reduce negative attitudes toward outgroups.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.sample: We will recruit up to 187 students from Rutgers University, Newark. Hypothesis 2: Compassion for others will mediate the relationship between self-compassion and attitudes toward outgroups. Higher levels of self-compassion will lead to higher levels of compassion for others and, thus, reduce negative attitudes toward outgroups.

attributes.title: Bullying and undermining behaviours in surgery:  A cross - sectional study of surgical trainee experiences in the United Kingdom (UK) & Republic of Ireland (ROI)
attributes.description: A cross sectional study of trainee experiences of bullying and undermining behaviour in the UK & ROI
tags: Bullying; Undermining; Surgical training; ASIT, BOTA, JCST

summary.value:
Bullying and undermining (B/U) behaviours are documented in the international surgical workplace. This cross-sectional study aimed to assess the prevalence of B/U behaviours within UK & ROI surgical training domain.

UK & ROI surgical trainees were electronically surveyed in July 2017. The survey was open for one month and sent to all registered trainees at Core and Specialty level by the Joint Committee on Surgical Training (JCST) along with email and social media dissemination by the Association of Surgeons in Training (ASiT) and the British Orthopaedic Trainees Association (BOTA). A consensus session on the topic was conducted at the ASiT Conference in Edinburgh in March 2018

registration_responses.summary:
Bullying and undermining (B/U) behaviours are documented in the international surgical workplace. This cross-sectional study aimed to assess the prevalence of B/U behaviours within UK & ROI surgical training domain.

UK & ROI surgical trainees were electronically surveyed in July 2017. The survey was open for one month and sent to all registered trainees at Core and Specialty level by the Joint Committee on Surgical Training (JCST) along with email and social media dissemination by the Association of Surgeons in Training (ASiT) and the British Orthopaedic Trainees Association (BOTA). A consensus session on the topic was conducted at the ASiT Conference in Edinburgh in March 2018

attributes.title: Does providing authors with customized article templates including items from reporting guidelines improve completeness of reporting? A randomized trial
attributes.description:
There is evidence that, although most reputable medical journals endorse the use of reporting guidelines, authors still find it difficult to identify the most appropriate one and use it effectively to improve the completeness of their article.  

We have developed an online tool called GoodReports (www.goodreports.org) to help researchers find and use reporting guidelines. The tool currently helps researchers identify the most appropriate single reporting guideline (e.g., CONSORT, STROBE, or PRISMA) and delivers an online, editable checklist that can also be downloaded. The checklist can be annotated to indicate where in the manuscript each item has been reported, then submitted to a journal alongside an article manuscript. However, pilot data collected as part of a collaboration with a medical journal indicated that when a checklist was delivered immediately before submission, it did not lead to authors making significant additions to their manuscript.  

Therefore, we plan to 

1. Develop the functionality of the GoodReports tool to deliver an article template to be used during writing. 

2. Combine items from more than one reporting guideline into a single article template, where appropriate.  

3. Conduct a randomized trial to test whether article templates delivered early in the writing process result in more complete reporting of health research articles.

q1.value: Caroline Struthers, Jennifer Anne de Beyer, Patricia Logullo, James Harwood, Gary Collins

q2.value:
Null hypothesis: 
If an author who is writing a research article for publication in a medical journal is provided with an article template including items from up to four reporting guidelines appropriate to the characteristics of their study, they will not write a more complete, transparent and publishable account of their work than if they are recommended those same individual reporting guidelines.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value:
Random allocation to one of two study arms using block randomization with random block sizes.

We will create a trial website with embedded randomization software that will ensure allocation concealment.

To confirm the eligibility of participants in terms of their study design, the focus of their study on a health-related topic, and availability of appropriate reporting guidance, all participants will be required to complete an online questionnaire before they enter the trial.  We will also collect basic baseline data such as previous experience of writing research articles. 

On completion of the questionnaire, participants will be randomly allocated to one of two study arms:

Study arm 1: Link to GoodReports article template including items from recommended reporting guidelines (intervention group)

Study arm 2: Link to recommended reporting guideline records (control group)

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited online via social media and other digital channels from health research and science writing communities. 

Targeted author communities will include EQUATOR newsletter subscribers, Penelope.ai users, GoodReports users, the AuthorAID community, medical writers (AMWA, EMWA), researchers who have registered studies on the ISRCTN database, and authors from our two official partner journals via their Guide for Authors page. 

Authors will be eligible to participate if:  

1. They are over 18, 

2. they intend to complete an original research article 

Original research types include trials, cohort, case-control, or cross-sectional studies, diagnostic test accuracy studies, prognostic/prediction model studies, preclinical animal studies, genetic association studies, healthcare service improvement studies, economic evaluations and systematic reviews.  The article can be a protocol for any of the study types.

3. They intend to complete and submit the article to a medical journal or pre-print server in the next 6-12 months, and  

4. Their study uses descriptive or inferential statistical methods (i.e., we will exclude authors of exclusively qualitative research studies).

Participants will be required to send the final methods and (unless they’re writing a protocol) results section of their manuscript for assessment by members of the GoodReports trial team. 

The incentive for agreeing to participate in the trial is a free manuscript check performed by the researchers. We will check for completeness of the methods and results sections against the “gold-standard” reporting checklist items appropriate to the authors’ study. This checklist will have been created by the GoodReports tool according to responses to a questionnaire taken by all participants as part of the recruitment process. 

The participants randomized to the intervention group will have received a template with the same items as the gold-standard checklist used to assess their article. 

The participants in the control group will have received links to up to four reporting guideline records on the EQUATOR Network Library (https://www.equator-network.org/reporting-guidelines/) and no article template. 

There will be no other incentive offered to participants.

We aim to open recruitment on 1 October 2020 and close it on 30 June 2021. We aim to finish assessment and data collection by 30 June 2022.

We have applied for approval from the Central University Ethics Committee (CUREC), University of Oxford as authors will be required to agree (electronically or in person) via a consent form for assessment of their de-identified manuscripts and publication of the assessment data. There is no physical, legal, or psychological risk of hazard or harm from this research to any of the participants.

q11.value: The target sample size is 206 manuscripts (103 in each arm)

q12.value:
We have pilot data from a before-and-after study of 20 manuscripts written by authors using the prototype version of the GoodReports tool. This delivered an online version of the appropriate checklist to authors who completed a questionnaire about their study immediately before submission to a journal. 

Five of the twenty (25%) manuscript authors added information to reporting items in the methods section of their manuscripts after having completed a reporting checklist on GoodReports.org. These five manuscripts went from 63% of items reported to 74% before and after receiving the GoodReports checklist, which is an absolute improvement of 11 percentage points or a relative increase of 18% (11/63).  

We will assume that our control group, who will be recommended a reporting guideline at an earlier stage of the writing process, will achieve a greater improvement in reporting than the pilot study authors. 

For this trial, we are comparing completeness of reporting between two groups, rather than measuring whether information is added after “exposure” to a reporting checklist. 

To measure completeness, we will have three categories for each reporting item: not reported (score 0), partially reported (score 0.5), and completely reported (score 1). 

We will assume that 20% of the control group will write a “perfect” report of their study, defined as reporting every item in the methods and results section of their manuscript completely.  

We aim for a 25% target difference, meaning that 45% of the intervention group authors will report every item completely. To achieve this difference with 90% power and a dropout rate of 30%, the sample size needs to be 206.

q13.value: We will close recruitment when we reach 250, even if this is before the end of the recruitment period.

question.value:
After giving consent, all participants will be required to go through an online decision tree (the GoodReports “wizard”), which will confirm their eligibility to take part in the trial and collect information about the participant and their study.  

Eligible participants will then be randomly assigned to one of two groups.  Participants will either receive: 

1. An online downloadable article template in Word combining selected items from up to four reporting guidelines (Intervention group), or

2. A link to the records of up to four reporting guidelines most appropriate to their study on the EQUATOR website (Control group). 

Both groups will be sent an email every month for up to 12 months checking the status of their article and reminding them to submit a copy of their manuscript to the trial team before they submit it to a journal.

We will collect baseline information about each participant’s level of experience of writing research articles and their awareness of reporting guidelines. We will not use this data for prediction.

The main outcome variable is the completeness of reporting in the methods and results sections of the articles written by the participants. 

A participant’s manuscript will be assessed against the checklist generated by GoodReports for their study when they entered this trial. Evaluators will rate the level of completeness of each item on the checklist as: 

●	Fully reported 		
●	Partially reported 	
●	Not reported/missing 	
●	Not applicable  	

We will also ask permission during the consent process to follow up participants with a participant survey. We will ask a range of questions about:

* Their experience of using the GoodReports template or the reporting guideline recommendation(s) to help them write their article
* Whether they sought reporting guidance from elsewhere during the trial   
* The usefulness of the completeness assessment report
* Whether they submitted a checklist to the journal with their manuscript

We hope also to collect objective outcomes from the manuscripts of participants recruited via our two partner journals (`BMJ Open' and `Diseases of the Colon and Rectum') on submission and acceptance rates, time through editing and peer review, and the quality of the final publications.

Each manuscript will be given a score for each item in the methods and (if applicable) results section of its corresponding GoodReports checklist:

•	Completely reported items will receive a score of 1.
•	Partially reported items will receive a score of 0.5 
•	Items assessed as not reported will receive a score of 0.
•	Items assessed as not applicable will receive a score of –1, which will be subtracted from the total number of items in the checklist. 

Each manuscript will receive a completeness index expressed as a percentage: the total completeness score divided by the total number of items in the methods and (if applicable) results section, minus the items judged as not applicable

We will perform an independent two-sample t-test to compare the intervention and control group completeness scores. 

We will also plot the completeness scores between the intervention and control groups in the following subgroups  

Study type
•	Experimental studies
•	Observational studies
•	Exploratory/hypothesis generating studies
•	Systematic reviews

Author type
•	Early career/1st time authors
•	Non-native English speakers
•	Experienced researchers 
•	Medical writers

Study focus
•	Public health/epidemiology
•	Psychological/behavioural medicine
•	Medicine or surgery
•	Organisational and services improvement

q18.value: We will not transform the data.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining whether the t-test suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value: We will not exclude any data from our analyses. The data points are limited and categorical. We will perform double data extraction on a random selection of manuscripts by a researcher independent of our team to verify the accuracy of the assessments.

q21.value: Participants who do not upload their manuscripts within 12 months of recruitment will not be included in the analysis and will count as dropouts.

q22.value: We may investigate further sub-groups within the sample of manuscripts, such as author experience level, for possible relationships between these characteristics and the effect of the GoodReports intervention.

attributes.title: Cognitive evaluation and rehabilitation for pediatric multiple sclerosis: a scoping review
attributes.description: We conduct a scoping review of original studies from inception to February 2020 concerning the cognitive evaluation and rehabilitation for pediatric multiple sclerosis. PubMed, MEDLINE, Web of Science, and trial registers (ClinicalTrials.gov, European Union Clinical Trials Register) were searched for pertinent studies. Data charting and synthesis are performed.

summary.value: This registration contains the title and a brief description of the project.

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains the title and a brief description of the project.

attributes.title: Autobiographical Memories and Trust in Audience
attributes.description: The current project extends work from previous experiments examining how knowing an audience's perspective can influence how individuals reflect on their autobiographical memories. Experiment 1 of this project (https://osf.io/xpv7d) demonstrated that communicating with an audience who has a positive perspective on the memory topic leads to more positive attitudes related to the memory topic and more positive event memory perceptions than communicating with an audience who has a negative perspective on the memory topic. Research on audience tuning in regards to communication about the behavior of others has shown that the audience-congruent memory bias is greater when the communicator has high epistemic trust in the audience as opposed to when trust in the audience is low (Echterhoff, Higgins, Kopietz, & Groll, 2008). The current experiment will examine if trust in the audience moderates the effect of audience perspective on subsequent memory topic attitudes and event memory perceptions after describing a personal experience.

q2.value:
1. Replicating findings from previous studies, there should be an overall main effect of audience perspective on subsequent memory topic attitudes and event memory perceptions such that writing a positive audience will lead to more positive attitudes and event memory perceptions than writing to a negative audience.

2. If trust in audience is important for the audience-bias effect, then there should be a significant interaction of audience perspective x trust such that when the audience is nationally-regarded experts (high trust), writing to a positive audience will lead to more positive attitudes and event memory perceptions than writing to a negative audience. However, when the audience is high school sophomores (low trust), audience perspective should have a weaker effect on subsequent attitudes and event memory perceptions.

3. Replicating findings from previous studies, shared reality should also moderate the effects of audience perspective on attitudes and event memory perceptions such that the audience-bias effect should be more pronounced for individuals who experience greater shared reality than those who experience low shared reality. Exploratory analyses will be conducted to examine the relationship of trust in audience on shared reality.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The study will use a 2 X 2 x 2 between-subjects design. Participants will first be randomly assigned to a memory topic (multitasking OR group work). Next, they will be randomly assigned to an audience who is described as either nationally-regarded experts OR high school sophomores. Lastly, the audience will be described as having either a positive perspective on the memory topic OR a negative perspective on the memory topic.

q7.value: Participants will automatically be randomized in Qualtrics to a memory topic, audience perspective, and audience description.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: Data have not been observed or analyzed prior to this pre-registration.

question.value: Students enrolled in introductory psychology courses will be recruited to participate in the study via the online research participation system that is maintained by the Department of Psychology. Students will be compensated credit towards the fulfillment of a class requirement. All students of at least 18 years of age will  be eligible to participate. The study will run until the specified number of participants is reached, at which point all remaining study sign ups will be completed but no additional study sessions will be posted.

q11.value: The target sample size is 400 participants. We will remove any participants that fail the manipulation check. Therefore, we will recruit up to 440 participants, assuming that some participants will need to be removed from the analyses.

q12.value: Power analyses were conducted using G*Power 3 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). Meta-analytic results on audience trust in relation to audience tuning suggest that epistemic trust has a medium-sized effect, (r = .28) on the audience-congruent recall bias  (Echterhoff, higgins, Kopietz, & Groll, 2008). Therefore, a power analysis was conducted assuming a medium effect size (f = 0.25). The power analysis revealed a necessary sample size needed for an ANOVA with a 2x2x2 design, to test for main effects and interactions and to obtain a power of .80 is 158 cases. However, due to research restrictions surrounding COVID-19, the study had to be moved to online. Because participants may be distracted when taking a study online, we expected the effect size to be slightly smaller online. Therefore,  a subsequent power analysis was conducted using a more conservative effect size (f = .15) which revealed a necessary sample size of 432 to obtain a power of .80. We will aim to recruit 440 participants.

q13.value: Data collection will end once our target number of participants is reached and all remaining participants already signed up have participated.

question.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to a memory topic. The 2 topics that participants will be asked to write about are multi-tasking and group work.

We will also manipulate audience perspective.  Participants will be told that the audience (researchers) have either a positive or negative view of the topic.

Lastly, we will manipulate trust in the audience. Participants will either be told that the project was developed by a group of high school sophomores interested in the topic or by a group of nationally-regarded experts on the topic.

1.Event Memory Perceptions: Event memory perceptions will be measured with the following four items: How favorable would you rate yourself in this event? How likeable would you say you were in this event? How positive was this event? How negative was this event? Participants will respond to these items on a 7 point scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely). These items will be averaged to create a two scores: one for event memory perceptions, and one for self-in-memory valence. 

2.Attitudes about topic: Attitudes will be measured by having subjects indicate their reactions to the topic that they are assigned among the following evaluative word pairs: (positive/negative, like/dislike, good/bad, desirable/undesirable, beneficial/harmful, wise/foolish). For each word pair, participants will rate the topic on a 7-point bipolar continuum. 

3. Shared Reality: Shared reality will be measured with the shared reality scaled recently established by Schmalback, Rossignac-Milon, Keller, Higgins, and Echterhoff (SPSP, 2019). The scale includes 5 items assessing the degree to which people perceive a successful shared reality with another person (X) about a particular target subject (Y); (“I feel the same way about Y as X does”, “I think that X and I are on the same wavelength with regard to Y”, “I agree with X`s point of view of Y”, “X and I see Y in the same way”, “I agree with X`s perception of Y”). In this case, X will be replaced with “the researcher” and Y will be replaced with “memory topic”. Participants will answer items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

4. Trust in Audience: Trust in audience will be measured using the following 7 items adapted from previous studies (Echterhoff, Higgins, & Groll, 2005): Are the researchers people whose judgment about (memory topic) one you can trust?,  Are the researchers a trustworthy source of information about (memory topic)?, Do the researchers appear to you as trustworthy?, Do the researchers appear to you as a reliable source of knowledge?, Do the researchers appear to you as a reliable source of knowledge about (memory topic)?
Participants will respond to these items on a 7 point scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 7 (very much). These items will be averaged to create an overall score.

Preliminary analyses will be conducted to ensure that participants correctly interpreted the manipulations. Participants should indicate that the audience has a more favorable attitude toward the memory topic if in the positive audience condition than in the negative audience condition. Additionally, trust in audience should be higher in the expert condition (nationally-regarded experts) than in the non-expert condition (high school sophomores). Participants who fail the manipulation check will be removed from subsequent analyses. 

Each dependent variable will be examined by conducting a 2X2x2 ANOVA.  It is predicted that there will be an interaction between trust in audience and audience perspective, such that audience will influence perceptions to a stronger degree in the expert condition than in the non-expert condition. In all cases, planned comparisons will be used to determine differences between the three audience conditions, because we anticipate that the positive audience will lead to more positive perceptions than the negative audience. We will also examine whether shared reality moderates the effects of audience on subsequent attitudes and event memory perceptions, and we will examine whether shared reality is correlated with trust in audience. 

Lastly,  81 participants were collected in the lab before the study was transitioned to online due to COVID-19. Therefore, we will examine whether study location (online versus lab) affects the overall pattern of results.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the planned comparison tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. Confidence intervals and effect sizes will also be reported for all results.

q20.value: Participants who answer the manipulation check question incorrectly will be removed. Participants will also be removed if they fail to follow the prompt instructions by not writing about an autobiographical memory that relates to the topic assigned.

registration_responses.q2:
1. Replicating findings from previous studies, there should be an overall main effect of audience perspective on subsequent memory topic attitudes and event memory perceptions such that writing a positive audience will lead to more positive attitudes and event memory perceptions than writing to a negative audience.

2. If trust in audience is important for the audience-bias effect, then there should be a significant interaction of audience perspective x trust such that when the audience is nationally-regarded experts (high trust), writing to a positive audience will lead to more positive attitudes and event memory perceptions than writing to a negative audience. However, when the audience is high school sophomores (low trust), audience perspective should have a weaker effect on subsequent attitudes and event memory perceptions.

3. Replicating findings from previous studies, shared reality should also moderate the effects of audience perspective on attitudes and event memory perceptions such that the audience-bias effect should be more pronounced for individuals who experience greater shared reality than those who experience low shared reality. Exploratory analyses will be conducted to examine the relationship of trust in audience on shared reality.

Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

attributes.title: Alexa Weber Final Project
attributes.description: This study examines the persuasion that advertising against alcohol has on men and women compared to advertisements for alcohol consumption. Would the campaign of not drinking influence the individuals watching the advertisement or has the lifetime of alcohol promotion brainwashed the youth? The overall purpose of this study was to determine if campaigns against alcohol being shown on network television are truly effective.

q1.value: Alexa Weber, Madison Pristera, Caitlyn Pritchard, Raymond Zuhowski, Clare Conry-Murray, Thomas Joseph Harrison, Mackenzie Gillen, Minka Bolognese, Ella Campbell, Patricia Carballo, Sheahan Collins, Christen Dockins, Madeline Eickman, Maura Flynn, Robert Gentilucci, Ryenn Hayes, Amanda Herzig, Tess Hodder, Gabriel Legido, Ann McConnon, Michael McDermott, Alyssa McDougall, Kara McSweeney, Amanda Monetti, Corinne O'Neill, Claire Pier, Allison Quinter, Carley Rose, Lauren Rossi, Ashley Santos, Gabriella Senni, Brendan Steigerwald, Nolan Vagnozzi, Samantha Zupko

q2.value: After being shown the advertisement, I believe the men and women watching the disapproving campaign will have decreased feelings toward alcohol compared to when they were asked to begin with. Those being shown the advertisement for alcohol opinions will not be changed.This will cause an interaction between those viewing the alcohol advertisement.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a between subject design each with two levels.Depending on if the participant's birthday falls on an even or odd date, dictates which advertisement they see. One advertisement being a promotion for alcohol, while the other one is a campaign against alcohol. The participants' feelings toward alcohol are examined twice, this being the measure of the survey. Comparing men and women to seeing the alcohol advertisement or the disapproving alcohol campaign. The survey will allow a group of men to see each advertisement, then the two groups of men can be further compared. Same goes for women, two groups of women can be contrasted to each other.

q7.value: Depending on if the participant's birthday falls on an even or odd date, dictates which advertisement they see. One advertisement being a promotion for alcohol, while the other one is a campaign against alcohol.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: rough the use of snowball sampling, convenience sampling and social media, individuals will be recruited. The goal of the recruitment is to get around 50-60 participants. Ideally having 15 participants for each cell in the between subjects design.  The target demographic being college men and women who are between the age of 18-23. The intention is to try to have the most equal amount of each gender and race for the survey, thus creating the best results.

q11.value: The goal of the recruitment is to get around 50people participants. Ideally having 15 participants for each cell in the between subjects design.

question.value: Depending on if the participant's birthday falls on an even or odd date, dictates which advertisement they see. One advertisement being a promotion for alcohol, while the other one is a campaign against alcohol.

The question of “How do you feel about alcohol?”,  is measured on a linear scale of one equaling a negative feeling up to five equaling a positive feeling. Whether or not the participant is viewing the alcohol advertisement or the campaign against consuming alcohol is controlled through the experiment. This being decided on if your birthday falls on an even day, alcohol advertisement, or an odd day, disapproving advertisement. This in-between subjects design allows the subjects of an experiment to be assigned to different conditions, with each subject experiencing only one of the experimental conditions. This way each group (whether you see the alcohol advertisement or the one against drinking) can be analyzed within itself, then compared to one another.
The question of "Your feeling toward alcohol" is asked both before the advertisement and after the advertisement to be compared if the advertisement changes the participants opinion.

I used a between subjects ANOVA to analyze the results. The defendant variable is the question of "how do you feel about alcohol?" on a linear scale of 1 (negative) to 5 (Positive). The independent variable one is seeing an advertisement for alcohol and independent variable two is seeing an advertisement against alcohol.

q20.value: outliers will be included in the data, there will be no participants excluded as long as they completed the survey appropriately and correctly.
